awd_titl_txt: Quantum Theories of Atomic and Molecular Interactions and their Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the world is made of atoms, it is not surprising that most of the important questions in science and technology can be put under the category of understanding a few-atom or a many-atom quantum system. This includes both the "big questions" such as the origin of life, and the more practical questions such as the everyday chemistry, biology, and medicine. While this atomic picture of the world is sound and natural, its implementation at the quantum level is so difficult that it has barely started. Both the brute-force approach of quantum chemistry and the often-over-simplified models of quantum many-body theory have key limitations with no clear path towards resolution. While some scientists are starting to pin their hopes on a future quantum computer, computation alone, even when realized, never brings the true understanding that has always been the symbol and the aspiration of science. This project is a part of a long-term program that intends to develop a new theoretical framework for the atomic picture of the world at the quantum level. It is from the perspective of atomic and molecular physics and is based on new and most efficient characterization of atomic interactions. The theory hopes to enable systematic understanding of complex quantum systems that are impossible to treat in the quantum chemistry approach and capture much essential physics that has been missing from simplified many-body models.

The foundation of the proposed framework is a new effective theory of atomic interactions, to be developed as a part of this project. It is a substantial generalization of the more traditional quantum defect theories, previously developed and formulated mostly for single-scale isotropic interaction potentials, to electromagnetic interactions of all types including anisotropic potentials and potentials with multiple length scales. This is one of the key ingredients that will enable the quantitative understanding of atom-molecule and molecule-molecule interactions, which are both where quantum complexity first emerges and the foundation for the understanding of more complex quantum systems made of more atoms and/or molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The atom picture, that the matter is made of atoms and molecules, is central to our understanding of the physical world. It has been very successful in explaining virtually all natural processes and phenomena in which the underlying atomic and molecular motions can be well described by classical, namely Newton?s, mechanics. When such motions behave quantum mechanically, which unfortunately is the case in most chemical and/or biochemical reactions of interest, it becomes extraordinarily difficult to extract quantitative information from the atomic picture. It is an example of knowing the equations, but not the solutions, because the quantum equations are so much more difficult to solve than the classical ones. The degree to which we can overcome these difficulties to build a solvable quantum many-body theory of atoms and molecules will determine the degree to which we can understand chemistry, biology, and medicine at a quantitative level.  Any appreciable progress in this area will likely be sufficiently significant to bring about the next revolution in science.

Broadly speaking, the difficulties we face in a full quantum realization of the atomic picture fall into two categories. One has to do with the interaction, specifically the atomic and molecular interaction which itself can already be difficult to treat especially when it is anisotropic. The other has to do with the quantum treatment of strongly interacting particles, especially particles that can attract and bind. This NSF grant has brought about breakthroughs in each one of these categories. They are the culmination of our effort over the past few decades starting around the year 2000.

The breakthrough in in the treatment of complex atomic and molecular interactions is a general formulation of multichannel quantum-defect theory (MQDT) for anisotropic long-range potentials. This work, entitled ?Multichannel quantum-defect theory for anisotropic interactions? is available as arXiv:2008.08018 (https://arxiv.org/abs/2008.08018). It is a breakthrough development because most atomic interactions, whether atom-atom, atom-molecule, molecule-molecule, electron-atom, electron-molecule, ion-atom, and ion-molecule, are all anisotropic in nature. For the very first time, we were able to generalize MQDT, traditionally a specialized theory mostly for isotropic potentials, into a general theory of interactions that covers all quantum systems.

The breakthrough in the N-body quantum system is a reformulation of the mathematical and conceptual foundation of the N-body quantum theory, through a new concept of rigidity, a formulation of cusp conditions for a general N-body system, and the generalization of the arrangement concept to an arbitrary N-body system. This work consists of two main parts. The first, entitled "Rigidity, separability, and cusp conditions of a wave function?, is available as arXiv:2208.06035 (https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.06035). The second, entitled " Arrangement and chemical complexity in an N-body quantum system?, is close to completion and will soon be made available on arXiv. Together these works form a new mathematical and conceptual framework to build N-body quantum theories capable of treating strongly interacting systems, especially systems in which some or all constituent particles can attract and bind, such as systems of a few atoms or many atoms.
